Early Access Review
								If you're looking for a competitive football management game where you compete against other real-life managers, 90 Minute Fever is definitely better than anything eles currently out there on the market and there is a lot more to come with regards to features and improvements.It's already possible to sink several hours a day into if you're into your management games, but you can also check in for ten or twenty minutes a day and not have any issues.I came from Football Manager Live and there is no doubt that 90 Minute Fever can be a worthy replacement. Would highly recommend this to any football fan, especially those who love Football Manager and want an online experience!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am a big fan of Football Manager 2016, having recently discovered the series and replacing FIFA in my life with it. Despite this, I am not sure if I will be buying FM17, and that is completely due to 90 Minute Fever. I have only had the game a matter of hours and I love it. Whilst it is not yet as in-depth tactically and administratively as the FM series, I have huge trust in the developers to take it in that direction and it is already huge fun to play. The direct opposition to other players is a huge boost and makes winning feel so much more rewarding and they have got the transfer system absolutely spot on. I can see that this game needs improvement to become truly life-consuming, but I love it already and cannot wait for updates and improvements.As a side note, I don't use steam much and so I really struggled to download and launch this game and then creating a club was very dificult for me. I emailed the suggested email address for help and resigned myself to wasting my weekend waiting for a reply, and even considered giving up and undownloading the game and giving up. Instead, I recieved an email in minutes from a super friendly, kind and obviously capable person (whom I assume is a dev) called Kris, who helped me for no additional charge and was just generally as friendly and as helpful as I could possibly want. I would pay for this game just off the back of how helpful the dev was, and highly recommend it to all audiences.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
 NOTE:  I recieved this game for a 2 months subscription due to a promotion by WorkTheSpace and the developers of the game.  This is also for a beta build that is missing features such as staff and an advanced match engine.So let me preface this review by saying what this game is not.Firstly, while it is heavily based on Football Manager, it is not a "ripoff" of Football Manager, the closest comparison however would be to an MMO version of Football Manager. Positives So firstly, what are the positives?One thing is community, in 21 hours of the game, I have only seen 1 negative comment in the chat which ironically was due to the community helpers asking for people to share their opinion for the game. Everyone that I have spoken to so far has been very nice and very helpful in certain aspects of understanding the game.The next positive is the fact that everyone starts on a level playing field. When I first launched up the game, I saw that I had an absolutely stunning 21 year old left back who was the best that has been found so far, but I was suprised to see that when I played my first league match, he also had some very good players.This game is not like Fifa 16 Ultimate Team where you have to buy coins or FIFA points to buy half decent players and there are zero microtransactions in this game (as of 18th July 2016)One extra part of the game I like is the "negotiations" tab. When someone accepts a bid for their player from another team, instead of that player going instantly to that team, a 24 hour blind bidding process starts where other teams try to sign that player. This system not only prevents cheating but it lets casual players ignore the mostly tedious manual scouting process that Football Manager offers.The last positive is that you can actually sign legends in the game in the form of a "youth intake" in the Youth Players tab, so far none of them are available, since they "unlock" from the 24th July onwards if I remember correctly, but it sounds like a very good system and the developers also have the player's wikipedia pages linked to them if you want to learn about their history. Negatives However there are a few negatives to this game aswell.Firstly, the match engine so far is not nearly advanced enough to be considered adequate, there are some stats that are far more important than others, for example strikers with good finishing are typically much better goalscorers than ones with better dribbling or better physical stats.One other feature that is suprisingly not in the game yet is the lack of a rating system for your players, in Football manager you have a star system that represents how good your player is compared to the rest of your team, however here the star system is used to represent reputation which seems somewhat meaningless considering a simple post in the chat can increase a players reputation due to the people viewing his player page.The last negative is the fact that you need to subscribe to play. The price is very tempting I must admit, and it does enable users to pay a small amount and if they dont like the game they can just not renew their subscription, but for long time players you have to pay a lot of money just to play the game for a year.This game has bucketloads of potential and I just hope that the developers will keep updating the game. I advise that if you wish to buy the game, get 3 months first and see how much the developers update the game.TL:DR+ Not P2W+ Very good community+ Actually fun for casual and serious players alike+ You can buy legends- Some features are lacking- Match Engine needs an overhaul- No direct rating system

number of helpful: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I find myself writing this review to try and be fair to the developers whilst at the same time hopefully helping some potential buyers from purchasing this game under false impressions.  I don't know exactly how one is supposed to review an Early Access game.  Everyone seems to be doing it differently.  I believe this game should be reviewed in its current state, but it clearly also matters where the game is going to end up as well, and it also is extremely important in my opinion for EA how well the developers are supporting and progressing their game.  First and foremost I would say: read the information on the store page, especially the Early Access information.  I have no idea how on earth anyone could possibly buy an Early Access game without reading this information first, but it seems many people do.  This game is in the middle of being developed.  Anyone expecting a completed game is going to be left disappointed.   That being said, I find the current state of the game highly enjoyable, as do many others, but it is certainly not for everyone. I believe it is causing a problem that is potentially misleading people, both with positive and negative reviews and comments, that pretty much everyone seems to be constantly comparing this game to Football Manager and the no-longer-existent Football Manager Live.  It is absolutely ridiculous and wholly unfair to the developers of this game for it to be compared to either of these games.  One of them is a single player game and the other one doesn't exist.  It just doesn't makes any sense to me. If what you want is a single player football management game, then you should not be reading this review - you should be playing Football Manager.  You should only stay here continuing to read my review if the online multiplayer aspect is important to you. What this game should be getting compared to are all of other online football management games that do actually exist.   Games like Hattrick, Top Eleven, Virtual Manager, Trophy Manager and the 100's of other games like these.  The thing that initially drew me to 90 Minute Fever was  precisely because of the online aspect and their promise of no pay to win elements as I absolutely hate any games that have these.  From all of these other online football management games the best experience I could personally find was playing Hattrick, which is in theory free to play but in reality you pretty much must have a membership package in order to play properly which can cost upwards of 20 Euros per month.  90 Minute Fever costs a fraction of this amount to play and in my opinion offers a vastly superior play experience to all of these other online football management games, even in its current state.  It's an added bonus for me that it also comes with the promise that it is only going to get better and better and better.   It is obvious that this game has been designed to have no pay to win elements, which is critically important for me - I wouldn't care how good this game were - if it was pay to win - I would not have any interest at all. This game is extremely challenging.  It is PvP on a balanced, well designed and fair playing field.  It is clearly designed with the long term in mind.  That you need to build towards goals over time.  Anyone who is unable to handle losing is going to struggle with this game.  Anyone with a 'win now' mentality is also going to struggle.  For me this is great, I want a long term and engaging challenge.  But this type of game is not for everyone.   I would say as a general rule, if you have ever quit and loaded up a saved game in any single player football management game because you lost a match you feel you shouldn't have lost - then this game is not for you - it's as simple as that.  There are no second chances.  Every single result has to be earned.  It is ruthless, it is challenging, it is emotional and it can be extremely frustrating at times.  But all of these things are what make the play experience so rewarding.  I want my success to have meaning, and the only way it will have this is if it is a real challenge to achieve it. As many other users have said in their reviews, I also feel this game has huge potential.   More importantly, I believe this game is going to live up to its potential because from what I've seen from the developers I am very impressed.  They are engaging with users, working seemingly all hours of each and every day, are very responsive, are highly active on the forums and have already released a major update to the game despite having been on Early Access for less than 1 month.  They are clearly very passionate and committed to developing this game.  How the developers engage with their community, how they support their product, and how much progress they are making to further develop their game, are in my opinion, the most important things by far for an Early Access game, and the developers behind this game I believe are right up there with the best you're ever likely to find working on an EA game.

content:
Posted: January 9
Early Access Review
								Ive been playing this game for around 11 months now so i would say i can give a decent viewpoint. The game is an entry level FML comparison and offers a great experience for those that enjoy footy management sims. It has both custom and  real life players which return as 16 year old legends Such as Paul Gascoigne or Valderama etc and every season these should increase in quality.Game play is good, you customise your team name, colours etc then analyse a starting squad, dont sell to quickly and look for some bargain quality players which are frequently available cheap. Then set up your tactics and compete against similar level opposition in qualifier leagues.The best bit about this game which differs from FML is that new guys can compete very fast and its proven time and time again in regards to finances and results.The second best bit is the auction style transfer system which does much more to eliminate and possible cheating which burdened FML. The ME is good but could be better , but i believe it is at the foremost of their upgrade plans along with a 2d engine and staff/stadiums.Community is great and one suprising factor is the developent team play in game and often contibute to discussion.Overall , a very sound investment.PS, i want to have Dirks babies xxAny questions whilst playing, you can see me at team name Borussia teeth.

Early Access Review
								"This game is legitimate trash I feel ashamed I put hours into it"The reason I have 100+ hours is due to the fact that nothing comes close to this game in terms of what it is, imagine something like dayz but dayz is the only zombie survival online mmo out there. You get the jist of it. The problem with this game is how random it is, you're literally playing with dice every match no players feel any different to one another unless a striker has 17 finishing. The updates takes months and they are so small and they do not justify the purchase I have made for this game. Took about 6 months since I've owned the game to add staff to the game thats just an example of how slow the updates are.The game takes no skill at all just have a striker with 17 shooting and you'll be banging about 35 goals a season, easy as that.The community consists of about 60 people and mostly ai who will stomp you regardless of the fact they have players out of position and with bad stats.This game has no way of telling you how well your team is doing with their formations etc because every game is random no matter who you're playing. e.g I could stomp a team with Theirry Henry in it then be stomped by a team with ali dia it's that stupid.

content:
Posted: April 19
Early Access Review
								There is way too much to say(have over 1800 hours on record in this game), so will try to simplify:- they claim it's "no pay to win"; however, they have set up a patreon page and every monthly built is ran by the patreons, who get special insights into the game and private session with devs; - transparency is the biggest problem: they invented a lot of concepts to provide themselfes with plausible deniability. This results in stuff like "100 users complain that X does not seem logical". Sure enough, the reply is coded in "well, there are hidden attributes you can't see" or similar, each time amounting to either unverifiable or only verifiable by those with direct access to the DB(so devs)- they hate free speech; plain and simple, they implemented a chat-ban feature where people can ban you from chatting without providing any reason or evidence; the idea is "if enough people blacklist you, then it must be a problem"; this has resulted in a group-power dynamic within the game; People are getting banned daily for speaking their minds.- they are UK-centric: if you are not from the UK, you will wonder why all uk-based legends in game have incredible stats, way better than most brazilians or argentinians or any other nation; if you don't subscribe to a worldview where UK players are better than everyone else, you will hate this- the ONLY part that is attractive about this game is the MMO aspect, because as a Player VS AI game, it's at least 10 years behind FM series. So you would think they would put emphasis on the one thing they have better than FM. Sadly, it is quite the opposite: save for a few cases, in general, absentees is rewarded, so is dodging games etc ... - warning: they also lie, so many people were deceived into buying this because on their sale page they showed a 2d match engine which still doesn't exist; this is false marketing, i will report this @Steam and hopefully they will make them remove the false marketing.There are a few lads that i found in-game that have made the experience worth it, outside of it i would not recommend this to anyone who enjoys logic and hates communism.(they have implemented extremely marxist philosophies in-game: it's not about merit, it's about spreading the wins, as they put it oh so "veiled").Last year, i exposed the devs on outright lying to non-technical users(am an experienced developer myself), they banned me for months from speaking, if you are ok with basicly being abused by larger groups and not being able to say anything in chat because "someone could get offended and he who is offended is always right" then, by all means get this game.In short, i don't recommend it at this stage or at least until they change their authoritarian ways. They have no problem taking monthly fees from you for months and then banning you for an opinion which sheds the wrong kind of light on them. They never even consider stopping the creepy stuff they do(btw, the devs are competing with the userbase while having access to hidden attributes, database etc - and you can see how lucky they get each time with their buys, it's uncanny), they only ever do "damage control". No intention of changing their scamming ways, sorry to report.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is already a very addictive and enjoyable game to play, even at this stage of development. When all of the planned features are implemented the game is going to be brilliant! The game will especially appeal to ex-FML players like myself!I've really enjoyed being involved in the beta testing of this game for the past few months.  The progress the developers have made in that time has been impressive.The developers are very hands-on and I have had a lot of contact with them.  They have a very clear vision of where they want to go with this game, and have excellent reasoning behind each design decision they have made.The fact that this game is NOT P2W is hugely important to me.  The main draw for me with this game is that to do well you have to use your skill and judgment, not your wallet.  Everyone pays exactly the same monthly subscription and contends on an equal footing.I'm looking forward to having more tactical options in the game and especially to the 2D match engine being introduced so that I can get a better view of how my tactics are working.  At this stage options are limited from a tactical point of view but the developers have been developing the match engine at a good rate and I have no doubt that the finished match engine will be very good.Overall, I can't recommend this game highly enough.  It's hugely addictive and the community is very friendly and helpful.  A must for any footy fan who is bored of playing management games against the computer and wants the challenge of testing themselves against "real" people!

content:

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								If anyone ever played Football Manager Live, the online version of Football Manager before it got shut down a few years ago, this is as close as you will get to that experience again.It is currently in the beta stage and far from finished but there is enough going on to occupy a manager for a few hours a day.I'd say it is a risk running a subscription fee during this process as most players are getting free month codes and it will be hard to determine the games population once those run out but I believe the finished product will well be worth it.It does need work as I said but the developers are open with the players and have already implemented a few suggestions so they are wiling to cater to their customers if suggestions are sensible and can improve the game.Recommended for any football fans that want a decent mmo experience at football management.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
Early Access Review
								A new genre for any Football Manager fan. its basically football manager as an MMO, you create a team name and badge and get given a sqaud of players. these players are of mixed quality but at a level that can compete with more established teams, The transfer system is set in a way to promote fairness and resrtict cheating by using an ebay style auction system. working your way through the divisions while assembling a team made up of real life retired players and random generated players adds another element of strategy to the game, while the ME needs more development i understand that the devs are focusing as much time as possible on creating a brand new ME which is due fairly soon, and in my honest opinion i think that once the new ME is released this will be an absolutly awesome game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								(Early Access Review)The base game even in early access is very good; and while I haven't read ANY of the reviews posted on this game, I suspect that new players with little patience or an aversion to analytics may find the early access version boring at times, and for that reason I would say that "adults" are the target market for early access.So if you are a sucker for management games and love football then definitaly give this a go. If you also enjoy playing the fantasy football leagues (e.g. FPL, etc.) and are forever tinkering away at your team while fighting the urge to do extra transfers each weak then this game is a must-buy. Your FPL team will love you for it. The exciting upcoming feature in a couple of weeks is the introduction of youth leagues. I suspect this will more than adequately satisfy those that find 90MF a bit slow at the present.  For it to be truly great however (as with most mmo's) it could do with a larger base. So don't be shy, you'll just make the game bigger and better and have a say in how it evolves, Based on the effort, comittment, communication, involvement, and approachability displayed by the Devs and Admins I would rate this game as having tons of genuine potential beyond what is already a good game.There are no smoke and mirrors about this dev team - they are working to make it better, and genuinely value your opinions and in my experience have been fantastic. You will see the devs/admins actively engaging the game community via the forums, podcasts, and often hangout online in the game chat lobby where they are willing to answer random questions, take feedback, provide updates, and generally listen and respond to the player base on the smallest to the biggest issues. In this day and age, i find this level of interaction very refreshing and as such should be celebrated as a big positive. So for those that can relate to my review, my Buy/Sell/Hold recommendation is:    BUY

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								For all those of you looking for a new FML, I have one thing to say. Forget it. This game, at least at the time being, is awful. The match engine is totally random. There is absolutely nothing you can do and change the outcome of a match, unless the engine wants it. The match is only commentary at the time being, consisting of like 10 phrases. There are no corners in the matches.  Player stats and positions don't make sense. Players with awful stats for some reason shine and others with decent stats just don't. Positions do not matter, a player that plays naturally as DC and performs, will perform even as an AMC or ST. Game economy is broken already in my opinion and the "returning stars" feature is a joke as these players will become superstars even if they play regularly or not. Overall, this game should not have been released yet. I really hope that it will manage to become something close to FML we all miss but at the time being, I feel that it is one of the worst games I've ever played.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Wow where to begin...Clunky & ugly UI.To many inactive players / 'ghost' leagues.Match engine (back to the 90's) commentry only.Commentry is basic & limited to same few dozen things repeated.Game engine is just awful, hardcore RNG & 100% roll of dice.Game engine has so many issues, dozens of cards per game,Unrelistic ratings/scorelines(Screenshot on my Steam profile from 90MF of a game i won 15-5)Game lacks detail & depth of info, options & configuration.Player profile page very basic, custom badge tiny, no profileinfo or awards etc.Buy buying/selling market is poor.No stadium config/upgrades.No skill trees for training or alike.No reserve team/youth team.Game lacks any content or depth.Wiped my account (with active subscription)Players can grief other players by bidding on their players,which inturn makes the players wage go up at the end of theseason.Basically i could go on all day on how poor this game is & howmuch it lacks in comparison to FMLive (which had its own flaws)but it had depth, content, money  leagues, a large activecommunity, active admins (who did their job) all of whichthis game has no of & what it does have is implemented poorly.Yes it is an indy game & no it's not FM nor is it trying to be,but FM is the benchmark for comparison & this game went intoearly access WAYYY to soon as i saw a large chunk of playersleave within the first month, then the leagues got merged &inactive leagues were made for the inactive teams, but it wasto little to late for me, even so i played mainly AI throughoutmy time in the game, the so called 'prime time' league i wasin had more then 3-4 daily regulars including myself.This game was alpha when i got it & it is so far of beta imo,the game has a very small community with there being a small'click' of regular players who think they are above everyone& love to troll you in the main lobby chat if you don't conformwith their opinions, there are hardly (if any) admin/moderators& seem to be a bit to familiar with the regualr players imo,little to no intervention from mods/admin like in other gamesthe mods would cool off any heated talk before things kick off.I bought a 12month subscription & played this game for about5-6 weeks but as the game was a farcry from where it needsto be i stopped playing for 7-8 weeks with my sub still paidfor & active i was told my team would go into one of theinactive leagues until my return...Unfortunately the return was not off to a good start as thegame failed to load correctly & i had to email in to get itsorted (which they did) & the next day i was online only tofind a whole new team & no cash! i emailed asking for eitherrefund or replace got no reply, next day 2mill landed in myaccount which is what you start with, but less than what ihad when i left :(Basically the 90's Champ Managers had more content, betterdetail & a clean UI & a working match engine, all of whichthis game lacks, so basically if you liked Champ Manager &the newer FM games, then don't waste your time playing this,it's only selling point is the multiplayer aspect & the onlyalternative to FMlive, but you hardly get to play a realperson so pointless really...

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing FM for 15 years and also played FML, so was naturally attracted to this game. But even though I tried to keep an open mind because of the early access, this game is too short on quality at the moment and I can't recommend it, even as a work in progress. Main impressions are:1/ Lack of activity from players: I didn't expect this to be the worst feature of the game, but it was for me. Basically there is hardly anyone to play with, and you end up playing most of your games randomly against the AI. Most days you'd log on, there is no-one online so you can't play, you log off, try the next day. Then some days later, all fixtures pile up and you click through games agains AI opponents.I guess this one is a bit of chicken and egg, because the game is so undeveloped there aren't many active players, which makes the in-game activity worse. But I wish the devs found a better match-timing algorithm to make this a bit better at least.2/ Player attributes: almost all of these seem way too random, e.g. a center back with 15 finishing, 3 pace, 5 tackling and 15 endurance. With a totally random name and nationality. More care is needed with attributes and players, instead of just passing stuff through a random number generator.3/ Match Engine: as others have said, this is very rough and feels pretty random, too. I finished second-bottom of my qualifying league the first season, next season with the same tactic I was consistently in the top 4 of the Afternoon league. Because of this randomness, and because commentary is very simplistic you can't tell what changes to make to your tactic and just end up stabbing around in the dark.4/ UI is clunky and doesn't work well on the Mac.One positive is that the people in the game seem really nice, both players and debs, I really hope this game becomes a success with further development, and I'd like to reconsider it in the future. But at the moment it seems a bit stuck in a rut; you should feel free to try it for a month or two, but otherwise I'd at least wait until full release.

number of helpful: 13 of 31 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Summary: Not currently worth the subscription fee. Plays reasonably well and never crashed on me, but the massive amount of missing features (compared to Football Manager) and general lack of things to do in the game prevent me from recommending it at this time.The good:-Helpful community-Runs fairly well (though the UI is slow at the moment)-Those familiar with Football Manager will pick it up quicklyThe bad:-Match results are basically random. Playing with an attacking mentality seems to cause my team to concede more, but that's about the only consistency I've found. Possession, for example, seems to be totally random and not at all effected by match mentality or passing style, or even home versus away.-Tactics are limited to choosing your formation and setting a few match parameters (match mentality, passing style, closing down). Seriously, that's it. There are no individual playstyles for any position. If you want one of your central midfielders to act more defensively or offensively, the best you can do is put a player in that position with attributes that match how you want them to play. But even then, the game gives no indication of how (or if) player attributes are used for different positions.-The match itself is currently only viewable in commentary form. Not even a 2D topdown view is available yet, although you would think so if you watched the preview videos.-Player development has not yet been implemented. About the only things that can happen to your players right now are injuries, disiplinary actions, and reputation changes. The latter seems to be based on match performance versus matches played, and seems to only effect the player's value.-When you create a team, the game places you into a league with other newly created teams. The only options you have are to play in that league or to play friendlies. The problem is that in order to play against a team in your league, the other player has to actually be online and up for a game. That makes sense from a tactical perspective, but when half the teams in your league either never play a match or quit the game after just one or two matches, it really takes away from the realism.

number of helpful: 5 of 19 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really struggle to understand how people can give positive feedback according to the "potential" of something.The game is so poor of contents at the moment that there's basically nothing to do but playing boring matches on commentary only.You have to be honest guys, as EA and paying a monthly fee you should require much more.Matchdays are commentary only, you can choose how to deploy your players on the pitch but tactically there are FOUR instructions to set only (!!!), you have to imagine how the opponents play because there is no info about their tactic or strategy and a couple of statistics shown on a widget. Results are completely random and you have zero control on anything going on with the match. Things happen just out of the blue and you have to deal with it.Roles are completely messed up. You'll find that your striker can play DC, DR and AMC, and his attributes are awful in all these roles. Attributes don't seem to have a meaning anyway. Once  you finished your match... well there's nothing to do more, really. You can have a nice chat with few people hanging around and have a look a the market, and that's all.I read many comments about how this is better than FML and how this is so addictive. I wonder if they're playing something different. How can this be compared to any FM is a mistery, and if ever, this game looks so much to FML that at least can be said to be as fun as its big bro.You don't even have (yet) 2D to watch match highlights, I can accept this in 1992, not in 2016, you have no training system, no coaches system, no facilities improvements, no stadium features, there is not even a proper development of players and if there is one you don't how how it works.I don't understand how this can be successfull where FML failed.I want to reconsider 90MF in some months after a lot of work has been made but until that day I would not recomend this game to anyone.

number of helpful: 6 of 22 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								After playing for over a month and having all my opinions and constructive criticism completely ignored by the developers, I was left with no other choice but to quit the game, and change my review, which was initially positive, to negative, and explain why, so that everyone who is thinking about purchasing this game, doesn't waste money like I did.I started the game in the beginning of July, so I had a whole season to try out several tactics, linups and strattegies. None of it did anything as the results are totally random, substitutions have no effect, red cards have no effect, and playing home has no effect. I finished mid table, losing more games against offline teams then against online teams.As it was just the first season, and it was the qualifying season, I thought I would give it another go, and play the regular season, wrongly thinking that the regular season would have more active online teams, because I would think that the developers would obvously remove the inactive teams or put them in a different league. Boy was I wrong!After starting the new season, I realized that now there were even less active teams, it turns out all inactive teams qualify to the regular competitions just like the active teams, this is SOOOO WRONG! This said, I am quitting today, after seven days (this season), AND, this is very important: during the 7 days that the season has had so far, there were only 4 games played in total for the whole league, and 2 of them were mine, very active and interesting to play right? BEWARE, this is a GHOST game, and you will be playing with GHOST teams, and worst, you will more likely lose a game against a ghost team then an actual active team. I said this to the developers and I'm saying it publicly now, this attitude of keeping inactive teams in the game and having them winning matches, will not only keep them inactive, but it will also turn active teams like mine, into inactive ones. The developers are more concerned about getting new features, than to actually work on the urgent matter of game play and inactive teams dominating the game and turning this game into artificial intelligence matches rather than an actual online multiplayer game.This said, goodbye! And for newcomers, stay away, don't waste your money.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't bother. The first season (= month) you are in a qualifying league, which is some fun. Then you get into a real league and you may very well be the only one (or nearly the only one) who plays at all. Which means you just don't meet any other     players of your league unless you are really lucky. For me it was one game in a week (and three games at all in my league being played). The concept of this game is new and creative but it lives (and dies) with the number of players.
